content.webTitle: Guardian journalist wins Association of British Science Writers award

fields.headline: Guardian journalist wins Association of British Science Writers award
fields.bodyText: Guardian science correspondent Hannah Devlin has won an Association of British Science Writers (ABSW) award. The ABSW’s awards aim to reward excellence in science, technology, engineering and mathematics journalism. Hannah Devlin won the News Item of the Year category for her piece ‘Scientists to grow ‘mini-brains’ using Neanderthal DNA’. The story explores how geneticists are comparing prehistoric and modern biology to help understand what makes humans unique. The judges commented that they ‘were absolutely blown away by this amazing idea’ and described the article as ‘completely exclusive and original’. Hannah Devlin, science correspondent, Guardian News & Media says: “It was such a great opportunity to get to visit this team of scientists, who are attempting to grow mini Neanderthal brains in the laboratory. The science they’re doing is incredible and it’s an honour to have won the ABSW news prize for my story about their work.” A full list of winners can be found here.
